text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And also… Family Member: And does he do it here in the office with you guys? Doctor: So typically it’s an injection. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And there’s also a yearlong implant that you can do. I wouldn’t do it for your first injection, Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: but um the injection is just liquid medication that gets injected and it forces your testosterone level to go down. Patient: Okay. text: Patient: - seminal vesicles and (patient talking over doctor) Doctor: So when we talk about side effects there’s always the potential – Patient: Right. Doctor: - for you know unintended injury to things in that area like the bladder, the urethra, ah the colon which - or the rectum which sits right behind. Patient: Sure. Doctor: You can have things like blood in the urine. You can have problems with healing in that area. That’s why we don’t automatically refer people immediately… Patient: Sure. Doctor: …after surgery because we want the healing process to be well established before we throw in kind of a wild card like radiation that Patient: Mmm. Doctor: might have some impact on healing. text: Family Member: The only difference is Dr G___ was emphatic about having T__ call him after he had visited with you because he would like to know what you had to say. Doctor: Okay, well my sense is you know he and I can talk about sort of when’s the right time to get new pictures, and the lung stuff is interesting because is it just cancer in your lung that causing this gasping, this wheezing? Patient: He doesn’t think so. Doctor: I don’t think so either, but you’d have to rule that out because that can complicate sometimes clinical trials- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: because using experimental therapies in somebody who’s got something else going wrong that’s not the cancer or the therapy- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: when you’re on a trial we can sometimes blame the new drug for that symptom and then that drug gets a black eye. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So companies want to make sure that you’re good to go on and they’re not going to get a black eye because there’s something going on that’s not related to what they’re doing. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Yes, understand.

text: Patient: Yeah, but if needs be, we can do it, we can do it. There’s another drug that we were on, too, besides Lupron. Doctor: It’s called Zytiga, also known as Abiraterone. Patient: It’s Zytiga. Right. Zytiga. Doctor: And one of the things that you and I have discussed before, and that this might be true especially if you don’t participate in the trial, would be you know could we start the Zytiga without the Lupron. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay, in other words, could we have your oral therapy with the absence of or without the Lupron? Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And as we discussed before, this is generally considered a little bit controversial. It’s not the standard therapy. So if you read a textbook about managing advanced prostate cancer it would only say that you’d give Abiraterone you’d also give an injectable suppression at the same time like Lupron. Patient: Okay. Doctor: However, as I told you before, I have used Abiraterone (Zytiga) Patient: Yes, I have also, and I think I was zero point something for over a year. Doctor: Yeah, about point one.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: He was awarded a grant. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So because it was a transformative impact grant, we decided to call the trial the Transformer Trial. So this is a study where we’re testing this high-dose testosterone therapy. Patient: Sure. Doctor: Now there are a few caveats about the trial that you need to be aware of. If your PSA goes above one after we do those scans (we can talk about that in more detail) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: One caveat is, and this is going to seem more paradoxical, is that where patients go in this high-risk testosterone trial, the Transformer Trial, they also have to continue the Lupron. Patient: Lupron. Doctor: Which is a hormone-suppression. Patient: Yeah, yeah, we’ve had that before. Doctor: And that may seem paradoxical to you because on the one hand I’m telling you we’re going to give you testosterone back, and on the other hand I’m telling you we’re going to be giving you Lupron to suppress the testosterone. And it turns out this this is exactly what we want to do. Patient: Uh huh.

text: Patient: I feel pretty good. Doctor: Hospitalized? Patient: No. Doctor: And you’re here today because you had a follow-up or other reasons? Patient: For a follow-up, yeah, yeah. Patient: No. Well some swelling. (pause and ruffling sounds) Doctor: A little bit. No bumps at all up here. No pain, no itching. Patient: No. I noticed some weakness in my right leg. Doctor: They drew blood today. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Last week? Patient: Last week, yes, and my PSA jumped up tremendously. This is from last year. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: The good thing about that in addition to the survival is you have pain relief with that. So, actually if you didn’t have any pain, I couldn’t get that cleared through insurance because they only want people who have discomfort and pain. I’m not saying you have to be writhing on the floor Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: but you have to sort of say oh, yeah, I get pain so, you know, I know I have cancer. Um, but you’re actually a good candidate for that. You’re otherwise all your blood counts and everything is also good because if you were already coming in here with low white cells or low red cells you wouldn’t be great but you don’t have that problem. So, Patient: Okay. Doctor: maybe the next step should be this medicine called Xofigo which, you know, we can have a side effects sheet given to you. We have to run it through insurance. text: Patient: Yeah. I understand. Doctor: So here with the observation we are SBRT and you have a crossover. The crossover goes from the observation group to the therapy group. Okay. The crossover is basically gonna happen whenever or if the PSA level decreases by fifty percent of baseline. Patient: The baseline meaning my initial baseline – have to begin with or the baseline for this? Doctor: Baseline for this trial. Patient: The baseline for this would be somewhere around twenty-eight. Doctor: Correct. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Correct. So fifty percent above increase above would be fourteen points. Twenty-eight plus fourteen, that’s forty-two. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So and the PSA is measured every month. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you went on this trial –

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
